Dr. Walker Advocat to the Commonwealth, and these many years accounted a ci-villain; he with his two procters, Suckling & Frankling were well experienced in condemning the Dutch Prizes, where each one of them could get 1000 l. for his share in a morning. For whatsoever these two eager hunters could discover, the third being Advocate would certainly have it condemned as prize, by which means they have each of them gotten very great Estates both in Land and money.
Nathaniel Campfield Lieutenant Collonel.
Richard Chiverton a receiver of one per Cent of Merchants goods for redemption of captives.

Richard Hill (likewise) a receiver of one per Cent. of Merchants goods, for redemption of captives and a Commissioner for sale of prize goods, and was called to account by his Master before his partners and he were ready.
Stephen Estwick a Trustee for sale of Bishops Lands, formerly a Commissioner for the Customes, one of the City Militia, and go ta great Estate since the long Parliament began.
Iames Russell a Trustee for the sale of Bishops Lands, one of the City Militia, formerly a Commissioner for the Customes.
All Trustees for sale of Bishops Lands.

These were all Common Councill-men, and had such imployments as thou seest and have besides been doublers of loane moneys, and buyers of others loanes at 9 s. & 10 s. per pound, received their full interest at 8 s. per Cent out of the Excise, and their principle in good penny worths out of Bishops Lands, buying 6000 l. worth of Land, for 1000 l. in Arrears or loane money which they
bought for 4 or 500 l. benefit, which bargains were so many and so great both to Parliament men, Souldiers and Citizens, as 'tis no wonder they cared not for admitting of any offer to repay them the purchase money, and preserve the Church Lands for Church maintenance, but would rather ('tis to be feared) have continued the Army, Excise, Taxes their imployment and our Ruine, which God forbid.

Iohn Stone sometimes a Haberdasher in Friday street London, who was a zealous Common Councellman and Captain under Tichborn, and in some of Olwer's Parliaments, who carried the matter so well that he was preferred to be one of the Tellers in the Exchequer worth 500 l. per annum, besides other fees: Receiver Generall of the Taxes, worth 400 l. per annum, Controuler of the Excise and Customes worth 400 l. per annum: a Commissioner at the Wine Office, and one of the Committee of the Army, in all which places he thrived so well that he hath purchased many hundreds per annum, and a good summe in his purse lying by him upon all occasions.

Thomus Kelsey of a mean trade in Birchin-Lane: and not thriving of that, betook himself to the wars whereby his zeale to the cause advanced him to be a Lieutenant Coll. and a creature of Oliver's, who made him a Commissioner of the Admiralty worth 500 l. per annum, and one of the Major Generals of two Counties, whose salary for one County was 666 l. 13 s. 4 d. per annum besides Governour of Dover Castle.

Will. Steel at first a young practitioner in the
Law and used Guild-Hall: about the beginning of the Wars was chosen one of the City Counsell: and great Chairman of that all devouring Committee at Cambden-House, where he demeaned himself so well that he should have been Counsell with Cook and Dorislaus for managing the charge against his Soveraign, but it was his good hap to fall sick (as 'tis reported) of the small pox just at the instant: however he was afterwards made Recorder of London: then Lord chief. Baron of the Exchequer, and continued so, untill sent by his good Lord Oliver, Lord Chancellor of Ireland, where he remained untill he was sent for to be one of the 23. great Governours of this Nation in the Committee of Safety, in all which employments he was very active and as true as Steel.

Iosias Bernars of Clarkenwell, formerly a serving man. Bradshaws second and Haselrigs right eye, and ever as envious and fierce as either: was as forward for the ruine of the King and promoting the High Court of Iustice, both for the Tryall of the King and Dr. Hewit, though, by the continuall prayers and tears of his wife he sate in neither, yet his zeal was never the lesse, and so hath continued all the Rumps time, with that height of zeal against his Majesty, that he was one of the 16. Abjurators, which in all honest mens judgement is as dangerous to his Majesty and Kingdomes, as any thing possibly can be, and not in justice to be pardoned.

☞ William Goffe a Salter in London, whose time being newly out, betook himself to the Cause, went out a Quarter-master, and continued in the
Warres untill he had got what he fought for; and in time became a Colonel, and in appearance a very zealous devout man, much like his master Oliver, who sought after Greatnesse, Soveraignty, and Power; and praise of men, more then of God; as by their actions, and our woeful experience too manifestly appeared, by his complying with the Protectors Designes and Interests, got himself to be made Major Generall of Sussex and Hampshire, which was worth 1200l. perannum or what he pleased to make it, was of some of the mock-Parliaments, advanced his estate greatly, he was thought worthy to be in Lamberts place, and command, of Major Generall of the Army, and no doubt aimed to be Protector as Lambert did, was one of the Lords in the other House, and one of his Soveraigns cruell Iudges.

☞ Tho. Horton, in his extraction very despicable, who after he had been servant and Faulconer to Sir Arthur Haselrig lured fairly and percht on a Regiment of horse. A person of so little note that few knew whence he came or whither he went, unlesse to the internall Region, having sate as one of the Kings Iudges, and being of Anarchicall and pernicious principles to Kingly power.

☞ Tho. Scot by birth, son of a mean Brewer, and by adoption a Brewers Clark of London; who by being transplanted to Alisbury grew up to the Stature of a Sollicitor or Attorney. A little sneaking fellow, but a great lover of mischief, who closing in with our first divisions helpt to widen
them. A great pretender to piety, but much believed to be of a loose and lascivious life, having been said to have had the grincums. A diligent searcher after, seizer and suppresser of the Kings Books, or any thing written in his favour. A terrible man for a Commonwealth, having been a long Rumper, and Secretary to the Councill of State, having been one of the Kings Iudges and most impudently glorying, that when he was dead he desired no other Tombe, or inscription then this, Here lies Tho. Scot, one of the late Kings Triers.

div.head: The Names of the Militia of the City of London constituted by the Rump Iuly 7. 1659.

list.item: The 2. Sheriffs for the time being.

div.p: The generall Councell of Officers out of their Princely care for the set tlement of the Nations committed to their charge nominated, appointed and constituted these their trusty and well-beloved persons following to be a Committee of Safety, and that they doe consider of a form of Government to be established: and that they may as occasion shall require take advice concerning it with the principall Officers of the Army, and such other persons as they shall think fit, likewise that the time limited for bringing in the said form of civill Government be six weeks: viz.

div.head: Postscript.
div.p: WHat is defective in this small Tract, shall be more fully supplied in the second Edition. As for the Names and method in this piece it must be confessed there may be some little mistakes, it being the designe rather to observe the reality of the matter, then the nice circumstances of form; If any materiall errours have escaped, upon further enquiry and better information, they shall be amended.
